On 1/27/07, Bill de hOra <bill@...> wrote:
>  The problem in my mind GET a cached ID and sharing it with someone else.
>  If you want to serve IDs have clients use POST.

Correct.

If you're trying to solve this problem in a browser where
only GET and POST are allowed then you can use that POST to
create a new ID that is used in a subsequent POST.

If you are outside HTML forms then since you're POSTing
you mine as well create a new resource and return that via
201 and the Location: header. The client can then PUT a
representation to that newly created resource, and since PUT
is idempotent it can keep trying until it succeeds.

   -joe
